segment.source: Optimize your XAML markup
segment.target: Optimize your XAML markup

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Parsing XAML markup to construct objects in memory is time-consuming for a complex UI.
segment.target: Parsing XAML markup to construct objects in memory is time-consuming for a complex UI.

segment.source: Here are some things you can do to improve XAML markup parse and load time and memory efficiency for your app.
segment.target: Here are some things you can do to improve XAML markup parse and load time and memory efficiency for your app.

segment.source: At app startup, limit the XAML markup that is loaded to only what you need for your initial UI.
segment.target: At app startup, limit the XAML markup that is loaded to only what you need for your initial UI.

segment.source: Examine the markup in your initial page and confirm it contains nothing that it doesn't need.
segment.target: Examine the markup in your initial page and confirm it contains nothing that it doesn't need.

segment.source: If a page references a user control or a resource defined in a different file, then the framework parses that file, too.
segment.target: If a page references a user control or a resource defined in a different file, then the framework parses that file, too.

segment.source: In this example, because InitialPage.xaml uses one resource from ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml, the whole of ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml must be parsed at startup.
segment.target: In this example, because InitialPage.xaml uses one resource from ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml, the whole of ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml must be parsed at startup.

segment.source: InitialPage.xaml.
segment.target: InitialPage.xaml.

segment.source: ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml.
segment.target: ExampleResourceDictionary.xaml.

segment.source: If you use a resource on many pages throughout your app, then storing it in App.xaml is a good practice, and avoids duplication.
segment.target: If you use a resource on many pages throughout your app, then storing it in App.xaml is a good practice, and avoids duplication.

segment.source: But App.xaml is parsed at app startup so any resource that is used in only one page (unless that page is the initial page) should be put into the page's local resources.
segment.target: But App.xaml is parsed at app startup so any resource that is used in only one page (unless that page is the initial page) should be put into the page's local resources.

segment.source: This counter-example shows App.xaml containing resources that are used by only one page (that's not the initial page).
segment.target: This counter-example shows App.xaml containing resources that are used by only one page (that's not the initial page).

segment.source: This needlessly increases app startup time.
segment.target: This needlessly increases app startup time.

segment.source: InitialPage.xaml.
segment.target: InitialPage.xaml.

segment.source: SecondPage.xaml.
segment.target: SecondPage.xaml.

segment.source: App.xaml
segment.target: App.xaml

segment.source: The way to make the above counter-example more efficient is to move into SecondPage.xaml and to move into ThirdPage.xaml.
segment.target: The way to make the above counter-example more efficient is to move into SecondPage.xaml and to move into ThirdPage.xaml.

segment.source: can remain in App.xaml because application resources must be parsed at app startup in any case.
segment.target: can remain in App.xaml because application resources must be parsed at app startup in any case.

segment.source: Minimize element count
segment.target: Minimize element count

segment.source: Although the XAML platform is capable of displaying large numbers of elements, you can make your app lay out and render faster by using the fewest number of elements to achieve the visuals you want.
segment.target: Although the XAML platform is capable of displaying large numbers of elements, you can make your app lay out and render faster by using the fewest number of elements to achieve the visuals you want.

segment.source: Layout panels have a Background property so there's no need to put a Rectangle in front of a Panel just to color it.
segment.target: Layout panels have a Background property so there's no need to put a Rectangle in front of a Panel just to color it.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: If you reuse the same vector-based element enough times, it becomes more efficient to use an Image element instead.
segment.target: If you reuse the same vector-based element enough times, it becomes more efficient to use an Image element instead.

segment.source: Vector-based elements can be more expensive because the CPU must create each individual element separately.
segment.target: Vector-based elements can be more expensive because the CPU must create each individual element separately.

segment.source: The image file needs to be decoded only once.
segment.target: The image file needs to be decoded only once.

segment.source: Consolidate multiple brushes that look the same into one resource
segment.target: Consolidate multiple brushes that look the same into one resource

segment.source: The XAML platform tries to cache commonly-used objects so that they can be reused as often as possible.
segment.target: The XAML platform tries to cache commonly-used objects so that they can be reused as often as possible.

segment.source: But XAML cannot easily tell if a brush declared in one piece of markup is the same as a brush declared in another.
segment.target: But XAML cannot easily tell if a brush declared in one piece of markup is the same as a brush declared in another.

segment.source: The example here uses SolidColorBrush to demonstrate, but the case is more likely and more important with GradientBrush.
segment.target: The example here uses SolidColorBrush to demonstrate, but the case is more likely and more important with GradientBrush.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Also check for brushes that use predefined colors: and are the same color.
segment.target: Also check for brushes that use predefined colors: and are the same color.

segment.source: To fix the duplication, define the brush as a resource.
segment.target: To fix the duplication, define the brush as a resource.

segment.source: If controls in other pages use the same brush, move it to App.xaml.
segment.target: If controls in other pages use the same brush, move it to App.xaml.

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: Minimize overdrawing
segment.target: Minimize overdrawing

segment.source: Overdrawing is where more than one object is drawn in the same screen pixels.
segment.target: Overdrawing is where more than one object is drawn in the same screen pixels.

segment.source: Note that there is sometimes a trade-off between this guidance and the desire to minimize element count.
segment.target: Note that there is sometimes a trade-off between this guidance and the desire to minimize element count.

segment.source: If an element isn't visible because it's transparent or hidden behind other elements, and it's not contributing to layout, then delete it.
segment.target: If an element isn't visible because it's transparent or hidden behind other elements, and it's not contributing to layout, then delete it.

segment.source: If the element is not visible in the initial visual state but it is visible in other visual states then set Visibility to Collapsed on the element itself and change the value to Visible in the appropriate states.
segment.target: If the element is not visible in the initial visual state but it is visible in other visual states then set Visibility to Collapsed on the element itself and change the value to Visible in the appropriate states.

segment.source: There will be exceptions to this heuristic: in general, the value a property has in the major of visual states is best set locally on the element.
segment.target: There will be exceptions to this heuristic: in general, the value a property has in the major of visual states is best set locally on the element.

segment.source: Use a composite element instead of layering multiple elements to create an effect.
segment.target: Use a composite element instead of layering multiple elements to create an effect.

segment.source: In this example, the result is a two-toned shape where the top half is black (from the background of the Grid) and the bottom half is gray (from the semi-transparent white Rectangle alpha-blended over the black background of the Grid).
segment.target: In this example, the result is a two-toned shape where the top half is black (from the background of the Grid) and the bottom half is gray (from the semi-transparent white Rectangle alpha-blended over the black background of the Grid).

segment.source: Here, 150% of the pixels necessary to achieve the result are being filled.
segment.target: Here, 150% of the pixels necessary to achieve the result are being filled.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: A layout panel can have two purposes: to color an area, and to lay out child elements.
segment.target: A layout panel can have two purposes: to color an area, and to lay out child elements.

segment.source: If an element further back in z-order is already coloring an area then a layout panel in front does not need to paint that area: instead it can just focus on laying out its children.
segment.target: If an element further back in z-order is already coloring an area then a layout panel in front does not need to paint that area: instead it can just focus on laying out its children.

segment.source: Here's an example.
segment.target: Here's an example.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: If the Grid has to be hit-testable then set a background value of transparent on it.
segment.target: If the Grid has to be hit-testable then set a background value of transparent on it.

segment.source: Use a Border element to draw a border around an object.
segment.target: Use a Border element to draw a border around an object.

segment.source: In this example, a Grid is used as a makeshift border around a TextBox.
segment.target: In this example, a Grid is used as a makeshift border around a TextBox.

segment.source: But all the pixels in the center cell are overdrawn.
segment.target: But all the pixels in the center cell are overdrawn.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: Be aware of margins.
segment.target: Be aware of margins.

segment.source: Two neighboring elements will overlap (possibly accidentally) if negative margins extend into another’s render bounds and cause overdrawing.
segment.target: Two neighboring elements will overlap (possibly accidentally) if negative margins extend into another’s render bounds and cause overdrawing.

segment.source: Use DebugSettings.IsOverdrawHeatMapEnabled as a visual diagnostic.
segment.target: Use DebugSettings.IsOverdrawHeatMapEnabled as a visual diagnostic.

segment.source: You may find objects being drawn that you weren't aware were in the scene.
segment.target: You may find objects being drawn that you weren't aware were in the scene.

segment.source: Cache static content
segment.target: Cache static content

segment.source: Another source of overdrawing is a shape made from many overlapping elements.
segment.target: Another source of overdrawing is a shape made from many overlapping elements.

segment.source: If you set CacheMode to BitmapCache on the UIElement that contains the composite shape then the platform renders the element to a bitmap once and then uses that bitmap each frame instead of overdrawing.
segment.target: If you set CacheMode to BitmapCache on the UIElement that contains the composite shape then the platform renders the element to a bitmap once and then uses that bitmap each frame instead of overdrawing.

segment.source: Inefficient.
segment.target: Inefficient.

segment.source: Venn diagram with three solid circles
segment.target: Venn diagram with three solid circles

segment.source: The image above is the result, but here's a map of the overdrawn regions.
segment.target: The image above is the result, but here's a map of the overdrawn regions.

segment.source: Darker red indicates higher amounts of overdraw.
segment.target: Darker red indicates higher amounts of overdraw.

segment.source: Venn diagram that shows overlapping areas
segment.target: Venn diagram that shows overlapping areas

segment.source: Efficient.
segment.target: Efficient.

segment.source: Note the use of CacheMode.
segment.target: Note the use of CacheMode.

segment.source: Don't use this technique if any of the sub-shapes animate because the bitmap cache will likely need to be regenerated every frame, defeating the purpose.
segment.target: Don't use this technique if any of the sub-shapes animate because the bitmap cache will likely need to be regenerated every frame, defeating the purpose.

segment.source: ResourceDictionaries
segment.target: ResourceDictionaries

segment.source: ResourceDictionaries are generally used to store your resources at a somewhat global level.
segment.target: ResourceDictionaries are generally used to store your resources at a somewhat global level.

segment.source: Resources that your app wants to reference in multiple places.
segment.target: Resources that your app wants to reference in multiple places.

segment.source: For example, styles, brushes, templates, and so on.
segment.target: For example, styles, brushes, templates, and so on.

segment.source: In general, we have optimized ResourceDictionaries to not instantiate resources unless they're asked for.
segment.target: In general, we have optimized ResourceDictionaries to not instantiate resources unless they're asked for.

segment.source: But there are few places where you need to be a little careful.
segment.target: But there are few places where you need to be a little careful.

segment.source: Resource with x:Name.
segment.target: Resource with x:Name.

segment.source: Any resource with x:Name will not benefit from the platform optimization, but instead it will be instantiated as soon as the ResourceDictionary is created.
segment.target: Any resource with x:Name will not benefit from the platform optimization, but instead it will be instantiated as soon as the ResourceDictionary is created.

segment.source: This happens because x:Name tells the platform that your app needs field access to this resource, so the platform needs to create something to create a reference to.
segment.target: This happens because x:Name tells the platform that your app needs field access to this resource, so the platform needs to create something to create a reference to.

segment.source: ResourceDictionaries in a UserControl.
segment.target: ResourceDictionaries in a UserControl.

segment.source: ResourceDictionaries defined inside of a UserControl carry a penalty.
segment.target: ResourceDictionaries defined inside of a UserControl carry a penalty.

segment.source: The platform will create a copy of such a ResourceDictionary for every instance of the UserControl.
segment.target: The platform will create a copy of such a ResourceDictionary for every instance of the UserControl.

segment.source: If you have a UserControl that is used a lot, then move the ResourceDictionary out of the UserControl and put it the page level.
segment.target: If you have a UserControl that is used a lot, then move the ResourceDictionary out of the UserControl and put it the page level.

segment.source: Use XBF2
segment.target: Use XBF2

segment.source: XBF2 is a binary representation of XAML markup that avoids all text-parsing costs at runtime.
segment.target: XBF2 is a binary representation of XAML markup that avoids all text-parsing costs at runtime.

segment.source: It also optimizes your binary for load and tree creation, and allows "fast-path" for XAML types to improve heap and object creation costs, for example VSM, ResourceDictionary, Styles, and so on.
segment.target: It also optimizes your binary for load and tree creation, and allows "fast-path" for XAML types to improve heap and object creation costs, for example VSM, ResourceDictionary, Styles, and so on.

segment.source: It is completely memory-mapped so there is no heap footprint for loading and reading a XAML Page.
segment.target: It is completely memory-mapped so there is no heap footprint for loading and reading a XAML Page.

segment.source: In addition, it reduces the disk footprint of stored XAML pages in an appx.
segment.target: In addition, it reduces the disk footprint of stored XAML pages in an appx.

segment.source: XBF2 is a more compact representation and it can reduce disk footprint of comparative XAML/XBF1 files by up to 50%.
segment.target: XBF2 is a more compact representation and it can reduce disk footprint of comparative XAML/XBF1 files by up to 50%.

segment.source: For example, the built-in Photos app saw around a 60% reduction after conversion to XBF2 dropping from around ~1mb of XBF1 assets to ~400kb of XBF2 assets.
segment.target: For example, the built-in Photos app saw around a 60% reduction after conversion to XBF2 dropping from around ~1mb of XBF1 assets to ~400kb of XBF2 assets.

segment.source: We have also seen apps benefit anywhere from 15 to 20% in CPU and 10 to 15% in Win32 heap.
segment.target: We have also seen apps benefit anywhere from 15 to 20% in CPU and 10 to 15% in Win32 heap.

segment.source: XAML built-in controls and dictionaries that the framework provides are already fully XBF2-enabled.
segment.target: XAML built-in controls and dictionaries that the framework provides are already fully XBF2-enabled.

segment.source: For your own app, ensure that your project file declares TargetPlatformVersion 8.2 or later.
segment.target: For your own app, ensure that your project file declares TargetPlatformVersion 8.2 or later.

segment.source: To check whether you have XBF2, open your app in a binary editor; the 12th and 13th bytes are 00 02 if you have XBF2.
segment.target: To check whether you have XBF2, open your app in a binary editor; the 12th and 13th bytes are 00 02 if you have XBF2.
